label.text: Hold Note
Note Kind
A chart refers to the notes of a song as a whole including their placements, how on-sync the song is, and how good or bad the patterns are and charting is the act of placing notes in the chart.\n\n

When a chart is 'on-sync', it means the notes are synced to the beat of the song.
Syncing is one of the fundemental charting skills to make a good chart.
Offset is the numerical value of a song's sync. If the main beat of a song doesn't line up with the rest of the beats, then the chart is offset and leads to the chart feel off when playtesting.\n\n
An abbreviation of beats per minute which measures how fast/slow the pace of the song is with most songs being 4/4 time signature. (a measure is 4 beats)\n\n
Used to determine the number of beats in a measure and the type of beat in a full measure.\n\n

The top number is the number of beats per measure, if a song is 5/4, then a full measure is 5 beats long instead of the usual four, if it's 7/4, then a full measure is 7 beats long and so on.

The bottom number is the type of beat or note snap in a full measure, if a song is 4/8, it means a full measure is 4 beats long and every measure/beat starts with 8ths instead of 4ths.
The camera that controls the level or the 'stage' the song takes in such as characters and backgrounds and doesn't touch the HUD elements.\n\n
The camera that controls the heads up display like healthbar and strumlines.\n\n

Each column is a notelane, the leftmost column in a strumline is always 1 and only goes up depending on how many strums/arrows a strumline has and the chart editor has 4 columns, so 1, 2, 3, 4 which correspond to the appropriate strum/arrow.

This is useful when describing patterns in textfrom instead of screenshots and images, read more on the Patterns tab.

A strumline is a group of arrows/strums, BF's strumline is all of the strums/arrows that belong to BF.

The speed at which notes come relative to measures. 4ths means four notes per measure (beats), 8ths means eight notes per measure (beats + half beats) and so on.

Why is this important? Well, if you intend on making your chart on-sync, then all notes should be placed in the correct snap.

You can change the note snap by pressing Right or Left arrows or clicking on this to decrease or increase the note snap level.

If two (or more) notes are in the same beat, we call it a chord
2-chord: double
3-chord: triple
4-chord: Quad

Chords are commonly placed to put emphasis in the instrumental.
A special hittable note that does custom action wheather to play an animation from a character or trigger something in either CamHUD or CamGame.\n\n

Same as note kind but isn't a hittable note. It's a trigger that can put in the events column (right most column).
For example, controlling the camera movement throughout the song.

Pitch Relevance means placing notes in relation to the pitch of a sound (low, mid, or high?).
This is used to reflect specific melodies or parts of a song to make a pattern from the chart stand out from the rest of the chart.
Pitch increase from left-to-right or 1-4, if a note's pitch sounds low, it would be placed in 1 or 2, if a note's pitch sounds high, it would be placed in 3 or 4.

Why is it important? It makes patterns that feel slightly wrong to something that feels fun to play if used properly, some FNF charters also call it lip-sync charting because you're placing notes that match a specific vocal or tone (I.e. 'Bap' and 'Ah' = 3, 'ooo', 'ooh' = 2).

Not very similar to Pitch Relevance, but they serve the same purpose although the latter is frowned upon most of the time however because, if followed strictly, it leads tobad flow and awkward patterns.
How smooth a chart feels to play depending on how fluid the patterns and notes transition to each other.\n\n

Layering means placing notes that follow multiple instruments one by one, but there isn't a whole to it that can be applied to FNF charts since they're vocals only and when characters repeat themselves.\n\n
The first and blind playthrough of the chart.\n\n

Treat these as tips I recommend to follow and not rules you should follow as charters have different perspectives on what is considered a bad chart and a good chart.
BPM is provided by the composer(s) who gave the files (if not, ask them) If the BPM is set and you made sure the beats line up correctly then here goes my charting tips:

Apply PR as much as possible, but should be partially comprmised if the flow is lacking.

Recognise melodies and sections of the song, meaning if a certain section from the song repeats, the chart should reflect that by having the same notes copied & pasted.
This makes your chart consistent throughout the entire song.

If a melody is too repetitive and boring to play though, you could mirror the notes vertically or horizontally (i.e. 4→1 and 3→2) to still put emphasis on the melody without changing too much of the gameplay.
In regards to flow, let's say If the player character makes a repeated sound constantly (let's say 2), you don't want players to spam that key, make a two handed trill instead (1 and 4 or 1 and 2).
This may sound like you should avoid jacks at all costs, but jacks and minijacks are both very easy to mess up and very satisfying patterns to hit if placed smartly.
For minijacks, don't make 5 mini jacks in a row but instead have constant singles that transition to those mini jacks.

For jacks, you could replace it with a two-handed trill or a one-handed trill or minijacks depending on the context.

There's more to it when it comes to good flow, but it comes with playtesting and experience and playing other charts out there.

For scroll speed, I recommend just changing the value and pick what best works for your song via playtesting, but rule of the thumb is: the scroll speed can't be too slow nor too fast to sight read.\n\n
For difficulties, It's very important to consider what rules you should avoid in one difficulty and what rules you should follow in another.\n\n

Examples:

The Hard difficulty has chords, but the Normal and Easy difficulty shouldn't.

The Hard difficulty has runningmen, achors, jumpstreams, while the normal and Easy difficulty should replace those patterns with ones that are easier to sightread like rolls, a stream, staircase.

The Hard and Normal difficulties don't remove notes and use all note snaps in their appropriate spots, but Easy should remove all 16ths and above and be replaced with 4ths and 8ths instead.

Every charter has different rules to follow whether subconsciously or not, so it's important to have your own.

section-header.text: Make the chart consistent with your difficulty

label.text:
Players have expectations when hovering over a difficulty, if a chart doesn't follow those exptectation, it may be regarded as unfair or not fun.

Meaning, if most of the chart is singles only and then you decide to add a difficulty spike out of nowhere in a couple of sections, it's a bad chart.

If the easy difficulty of a chart changes nothing but the scroll speed, it's a bad chart.

Some players like slow movements to not make the notes blend too much into the background or have easier time focusing on reading the notes while others may think it's generic and needs variaty.

Like making rules for difficulties, you decide how often the camera should zoom, how long and what ease type, how often it should bop, when and where, and how (ease type) it should move from player to opponent and vice versa, and when to change a scroll speed in an event.
